set.name: MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 x Ethical Fashion Initiative
set.description:
MIMCO produced 1,532 bags in two styles as well as 1,532 accompanying dustbags in  Kenya as part of their Autumn-Winter 2016 collection.

A total of 86 artisans were involved in producing the order, from seven different community groups; Artisan.Fashion, Bega Kwa Bega, Olonana Women Group, Oldanyati Women Group, Nameni Eiroi, Namaiyana Women Group and Olanke Women Group.

75% of the artisans working on the order were women and 77.78% of the artisans were under the age of 40. All artisans recieved some form of training to help with the production of the order.

79.78% of the artisans used income received to fund the education of their children and/or dependents.

The different skills required to produce the order were beadwork, beading, crocheting, preparation, stitching, screen printing, finishing, final quality control and packing.

things.name: Olanke Women Group
things.description: A group of women who are highly skilled in beadwork. They live in a very remote area of Kajiado and walk long distances to meet in a central place in Kimuga to work. They began the group to raise school fees for the education of their children, particularly girls. They worked on the strands of the crown crane for the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order.

things.name: YKK Kenya EPZ Ltd
things.description: Sliders, zip chain, teeth and tape were purchased from YKK Kenya to be used for the zip closures of the bags in the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 collection.

things.name: Thika Clothe Mill Ltd to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Freeman's K LTD
things.description: Wax and cotton thread were purchased from Freemans K LTD in Kenya. They were used to prepare the fasteners for the accompanying dust bags of the bags from the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 collection.

things.name: Freemans K LTD to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Namaiyana women group to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Bega Kwa Bega to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Namaiyana Women Group
things.description:
A group of women who previously worked on their own. Two thirds of the group are young women under 30 years of age. They came together with an aim of consolidating their efforts to access bigger markets. They worked on the strands of the crown crane for the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order.

ARTISAN TESTIMONIAL

Lois Nyagothie:

I am 58 and a widow with eight dependents. I worked on the beaded strands of the crown crane during the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order. Although I am an old woman, I worked hard and performed on the order which young girls in our group were unable to participate in. This boosted my confidence and the overall satisfaction with my work. The order was challenging, so I did not earn to my expectation, however the income I received was enough to meet my immediate needs such as food.

things.name: Olanke Women Group to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Olonana Women Group to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Bega Kwa Bega
things.description: Bega Kwa Bega are a group of artisans with beadwork skills from Nairobi’s fourth largest slum - Korogocho. The majority are single mothers struggling to feed and educate their children in a harsh economic environment. They worked on the strands of the crown crane for the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order.

things.name: Olonana Women Group
things.description: A group of women specialising in traditional Kenyan beadwork. The women work together to earn enough money to afford sanitary towels for their daughters who otherwise would drop out of school. They worked on the strands of the crown crane for the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order.

things.name: Meera Smart Wear to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Meera Smart Wear
things.address: Meera Smart Wear, Ronald Ngala Street, Nairobi
things.description: Fishing line and poly-cotton thread were purchased from Meera Smart Wear in Kenya . Fishing line is a nylon cord commonly used in Kenya for fishing and beading. The nylon and poly-cotton threads were used for the construction of the bags in the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 collection.

things.name: Artisan.Fashion
things.description:
Artisan.Fashion is a social enterprise that was established in 2005 to connect Africa’s artisans to esteemed luxury brands all over the world. They are the first African production company to successfully combine artisan creativity and production capability with a careful consideration for traceable social impact. 

Acting both as a production hub and a disseminator of work, they employ Kenyan artisans in their hub and collaborate with 17 artisan communities across Kenya to produce hand crafted materials and artifacts made with traditional skills. 

To find out more visit: http://artisan.fashion

ARTISAN TESTIMONIAL

Asumpta Kanini:

I am a 32 year old mother of five. I worked on the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order as an embroiderer at Artisan.Fashion in the EPZ. I received a good income which I used to pay rent, school fees, food and other household utilities. The MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order was quite easy for me which made me enjoy my work throughout the order.

Michael Owino:

I am a 27 year old father of two. I am an employee of Artisan.Fashion at the EPZ. I worked on the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order as a screen printer. I used the income from the order to support my family and meet their basic needs.

Dorothy Oluoch:

I have six dependants. During the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order I worked as a preparer and in the finishing section. I am employed at Artisan.Fashion which meant that I received a regular salary during the order. I used my income of USD 150 monthly to meet school fees for the third term of 2016. I also bought clothes and met nutritional needs of my family. I was very happy to work on the MIMCO order as it also provided an opportunity for training.

Alice Achieng’ Omondi:

I am a 27 year old mother of one. I worked on the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order as a preparer. This order offered me the opportunity to train and to improve my skills. The income from the order assisted me to supplement my husband’s income. The order offered me economic power which has also afforded me respect from my husband who sees me as a very important partner in his life. I was happy to have work.

things.name: Inkson
things.address: Inkson Industrial Co Ltd, Ground Floor, Building 7, Dunga Road, Nairobi
things.description: Ink was purchased from Inkson in Kenya, these water based inks were used to produce prints on the bags of the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 collection.

things.name: Nameni Eriroi to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Artbeads Limited Nairobi to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Artbeads Limited Nairobi
things.address: Art Beads, River Road, Nairobi City
things.description:
Glass beads were purchased from Artbeads Limited Nairobi in Kenya,  who import them from the Czech Republic where they are seen to manufacture the best quality beads worldwide. The glass 
glass beads were used to to decorate both the bags and the zip pullers for the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 collection.

things.name: Nameni Eriroi
things.description:
A group of women from the Maasai ethnic community who specialise in beadwork. They came together to share experiences in order to ease the family burdens born by women. There were 20 participants on this project, of which 100% were women.

ARTISAN TESTIMONIAL

Eunice Mpeti:

I am 38, married and a mother of 10. I worked on the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order as a beader. Being a mother of many children I worked hard in order to earn more money to meet the nutritional and educational needs of my children. The order was a bit challenging, especially the measurement and finishing of the crown crane. I got on the job training which enabled me to perform well on the order.

things.name: Thika Cloth Mills Ltd
things.description:
Cotton canvas and cotton kitenge were purchased from Thika Cloth Mills Ltd. Canvas is an extremely durable plain-woven fabric used for making sails and tents in Kenya while kitenge  is a softer fabric worn by women, often wrapped around the chest or waist, over the head as a headscarf, or as a baby sling. 

Cotton Canvas was used for the construction of the bags while the cotton kitenge was used for the lining of the bags in the MIMCO Autumn-Winter 2016 order. 

For more information see Thika Cloth Mills website: http://thikaclothmills.com

things.name: YKK – Export Processing Zones Mombasa to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
Mahali Pa Watoto
things.description: Mahali Pa Watoto means a place for children in Swahili. The group is made up of young mothers who use their beadwork craft to provide food and education for their children.

things.name: Oldanyatti Women Group
things.description: A group of women living in the poor, rural area of Oldanyatti. It is mainly composed of Maasai women who produce beaded articles for sale. They created the group in order to reach a larger market.

things.name: Oldanyatti Women Group to Artisans.Fashion EPZ Ltd
MIMCO
things.address: Unit 490/658 Church St, Cremorne VIC 3121, Australia

google_places.adr_address: Unit 490/658 Church St, Cremorne VIC 3121, Australia
google_places.formatted_address: Unit 490/658 Church St, Cremorne VIC 3121, Australia
google_places.name: Unit 490/658 Church St

things.description: Upon completion, the 1,532 bags and their accompanying dust bags for the Autumn-Winter 2016 collection were shipped to MIMCO in Australia for them to deliver to their various retail stores. The bags can also be purchased from their e-commerce store online.
